Award.AwardTitle: Assessing Engineering Students' Understanding of Social Responsibility from Undergraduate and Graduate Education into Professional Life

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project seeks to understand the long-term impact of service learning on engineering students' career trajectories and their ability to make ethical decision making in their careers. The project will both develop fundamental understanding of service learning's impact on students as well as develop metrics for measuring the impact of service learning which can be widely adopted by the increasing number of engineering programs that utilize service learning in their curricula. One particular element of note in this study is that it engages current and former Army officers.

The broader significance and importance of this project will be that it will generate knowledge that can broadly impact how universities design and evaluate service learning programs, which is of particular relevance for engineering degree programs due to accreditation requirements. Service learning programs have been shown to attract a large number of students who are traditionally under-represented in engineering degree programs, thus this research may additionally result in increased diversity. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goal of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by supporting the development of innovative learning systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research project explored the development of professional social responsibility attitudes in engineering students and professionals. Social responsibility was defined as an obligation to act with compassion and consider the impacts of engineering decisions on society, with a focus on underserved communities. Socially responsible engineers will be more likely to ensure that their work has positive outcomes for society and the environment, while recognizing and minimizing potential negative impacts.

In the first stage of the project, a theoretical framework was developed, the Professional Social Responsibility Development Model (PSRDM). A written survey instrument was then developed to operationalize the PSRDM, measuring attitudes toward social responsibility across the eight dimensions of the PSRDM. The new tool was called the Engineering Professional Responsibility Assessment (EPRA).  Evidence of validity and reliability of the EPRA tool were found. About 3000 engineering students attending 17 different universities in the U.S. took the EPRA survey instrument. The resulting data identified differences in the average social responsibility attitudes of engineering students based on gender, engineering discipline, rank, and institution. A subset of the students completed the EPRA survey multiple times as they moved through college. In addition, about 30 students from different disciplines and institutions were interviewed once per year over a 4-year period. The survey data and interviews provided information about college activities that impacted students’ views of social responsibility, such as: a lack of any college courses that students identified as relevant to social responsibility (for about 40% of all college students); service-learning courses; courses that included ethics topics; co-curricular volunteer activities. Overall, more engineering students decreased than increased in their attitudes toward the importance of social responsibility.  A higher percentage of female students and/or students with initially more positive attitudes toward social responsibility decreased in their social responsibility attitudes. These results are troubling but similar to results from a study by Erin Cech published in 2014. In addition, among the cohort of students who participated in the interviews, female students who chose to major in engineering due largely to a strong desire to help others via engineering left engineering at a much higher rate as compared to students with initially weaker social motivations.  Interviews and surveys of engineering alumni found similar issues in the workplace. Some respondents had changed jobs because they felt that their position did not allow them to serve people and/or society to the extent that they desired. Some respondents had left engineering as a career entirely, due to concerns with ethical issues.      

The intellectual merit of the project includes the new theoretical framework and associated assessment tool that can be used to assess social responsibility. The tool could be used in a pre/post format across a course designed to impact social responsibility to measure effects on student attitudes. Other institutions and research are already using portions of the assessment instrument. To date, positive impacts on social responsibility attitudes were found due to courses that include service-learning and topics such as ethics and sustainability.  In most cases, however, these positive impacts were lost among overall curricula that emphasize technical elements.

The broader impacts of the project included training faculty and students in educational research methods. Two PhD students funded by the project are now teaching at universities. Nathan Canney is an instructor of civil engineering at Seattle University; he is currently the Principal Investigator on two NSF grants related to education. Greg Rulifson is a Teaching Assistant Professor in the Liberal Arts & International Studies Department at the Colorado School of Mines.  Three undergraduate engineering students also participated in the research, and co-authored papers for the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) annual conference. The research also provides insights related to the retention within engineering of individuals who are highly motivated to help and serve others. This group is over-represented in females, and therefore efforts devoted to infusing more social issues into engineering could help improve the gender balance in engineering. The results have been broadly disseminated via papers and presentations in multiple conference venues, and via journal papers (including some that are open access).
